citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was a female golden retriever (Ashly, 3yrs old) that had thickened and wrinkled skin on the inside of the ear flap.
The inner ear had some redness and inflammation with a dark brown greasy material throughout the ear. The ear had not
been cleaned recently or been observed to have any issues resulting in no treatment or veterinary care. While the dog
was not showing visible signs of dicomfort, the ear does need cleaning and the veterinarian contacted to determine if
there is any medical treatment required.
The lack of regular ear checks and cleaning as needed could result in possible ear infections or discomfort to the
regulated animal if not treated in a timely manner
The licensee must use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. A routine for
ear cleaning must be maintaned for all regulated animals according to thier program of veterinary care.
To be corrected by: July 19, 2023
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 inspections or by September 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was a female golden retriever (Ashly, 3yrs old) that had thickened and wrinkled skin on the inside of the ear flap. 
The inner ear had some redness and inflammation with a dark brown greasy material throughout the ear. The ear had not 
been cleaned recently or been observed to have any issues resulting in no treatment or veterinary care. While the dog 
was not showing visible signs of dicomfort, the ear does need cleaning and the veterinarian contacted to determine if 
there is any medical treatment required.  
 
The lack of regular ear checks and cleaning as needed could result in possible ear infections or discomfort to the 
regulated animal if not treated in a timely manner 
 
The licensee must use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. A routine for 
ear cleaning must be maintaned for all regulated animals according to thier program of veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by: July 19, 2023 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 inspections or by September 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
